title: Can novelists write about what they don't know? - Quora

response.answer_text: Nope.  If you write what you don't know it rings false, and that transfers directly to the page, and the reader will always pick up on it. To correct some misconceptions:  How many submarines did Jules Verne ride in?  None.  But he was intimately familiar with  the French submarine experimenters of the time - including the submarine "Le Plongeur" designed and built by Simon Bourgeois and Charles Brun, which (gee, coincidentally enough...) just happened to be around for seven years before 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea was published, and which Verne actually saw when he was writing the story.Fiction isn't about "what you don't know" at all.  It's about storytelling. Good storytellers write what they know.  They always have, they always will.Those who claim you should write what you don't know - using the "crusading knights" and "dragons" and "space travel" and all the Hogwarts stuff doesn't exist argument - clearly don't understand storytelling.  A story isn't about the inner workings of hyperdrive, the quantum physics of a witch's spell, the anatomy of a dragon or any of that ancillary 'color.'  A good story is about heroes and villains and love and hate and human emotion.  THAT is what good storytellers always write about; they write what they know.The Monomyth - which is every story - doesn't care whether you're in space, in a castle, in a well, fighting demons, learning magic, flying through wormholes or how a city can float in clouds.  It's about people.  It's about relatable experiences.  A good story is ALWAYS about relatable experiences.  The line wasn't "when the sperm found the egg in the fallopian tube and capacitation occurred and the egg was fertilized the DNA payload was delivered" because that wasn't the story and the writer didn't know human fertilization.  The line was was "Luke, I am your father."  Why?  Because THAT was the STORY. If you don't write what you know, you'll never succeed as a writer.

Think it depends on your style of writing/plot. If you are looking to write, say, a fictional story based on true historical events, then obviously, yes, you need to be able to understand and have knowledge enough to make the plot engaging and realistic and characters suitable, as they would be. Also, of writing in a strong historical setting you might want to be knowledgeable on the type of language used, ie a period novel, or a medieval one. Yet, I would say, as I have written several stories in specific settings, I really enjoyed researching the subject. And even though I felt overly intellectual on the subject before hand, while writing I uncovered many tiny, everyday facts, that I had no idea about, but were key in character personalities and ways they went about things (not being overly articulate, I apologise!) But yes, I would say, generally, that you do need to know quite a lot about the subject of your novel, in order to make it realistic and effective to the reader. As, remember, primarily, the people who are going to be reading your book are the ones who are likely to be interested/ educated on the subject- so would be no use or enjoyment for them, if the author had no idea what they were writing about! You might want to look at an author such as Michael Morpurgo, who was previously interested in certain subjects that he wanted to write about, but then did a large amount of stimulating research in those subjects and was able to write compelling and magical tales, amusing and educating children. For example, he has conducted  a huge amount of research into the first/second world wars and has become an avid writer in the subject, publishing many books, ie Private Peaceful, An Elephant in the Garden and WarHorse. So in this sense it is both key and effective to know, in depth, what you're writing about. But obviously, if you're writing something totally of your own creation, then you're already as knowledgeable as you need to be!

I admit I always laugh in my sleeve when I hear an author proclaiming you must write what you know. This tidbit of advice is often touted as a cardinal rule of writing, with the inherent implication being that if you aren’t 1) a brilliant scientist/mathematician/geologist/linguist/ tactician/psychologist or 2) an uber-wealthy jetsetter with the time and money to fly all over the place and experience everything possible then you really don’t have any business writing books. Fiction Is About What You Don’t KnowWhoever came up with this rule obviously didn’t credit imagination too much. In fact, it would seem said person probably didn’t have much imagination. Think about it. Fiction, at its very essence, is all about what we don’t know. William Styron said,  Isn’t all art a search for an answer to a question which can’t even be spoken? I have little to no interest in writing about the things I know. Not only would that curb my pool of writing resources, it would also limit me to regurgitating my life. And that would get pretty boring pretty fast. If I wrote only about what I know, all my stories would end up being about twenty-somethings who work at their desks eight hours a day, five days a week, spend Saturday mornings in bed reading, and encounter adventure and excitement mostly through their own klutziness and occasional stupidity. Not exactly what you had in mind for your next beach read, is it? Me neither. Why You Shouldn’t Write What You KnowI write about places I’ve never been, cultures I’ve never experienced, people I’ll never meet. The last time I checked, gunslingers, crusading knights, and dragons weren’t offering interview appointments. Neither can I afford to globetrot my way to Syria, Chicago, London, Nigeria, and points beyond. (We won’t even mention the fact that one of those brilliant scientist people I mentioned in the first paragraph have yet to perfect a time machine that would send me back to the Middle Ages or the Roaring Twenties.) But I’ll tell you a secret: I like it this way. Writing novels gives me the opportunity to experience what Idon’t know. If I lived in Chicago, I doubt I would have had any interest in writing about it in my fantasy novel Dreamlander. But because I’ve never been to Chicago—every moment spent researching these things was an adventure. Why You Should Write What You KnowIf fiction is about answering questions, then I certainly have no need to rehash my own life on the page. I live that everyday; the answers are right in front of me. I’d much rather experience the untouchable. Now, that said, let me do a major 180 and mention that I emphatically believe we should all write what we know. (Gotcha, didn’t I?) Knowing your subject matter is vital. But who says you can’t know it vicariously? That’s where research comes into play. If I wrote about the 12th-century Kingdom of Jerusalem and referred to all the natives as Israelis, I would promptly pop any knowledgeable reader’s bubble of disbelief and destroy my credibility as a writer. But, if I do my research, if I read the books, study the maps, and interview the experts, I’ll be able to write both what I know—and what I don’t.

Well it's the fact a novelist can't write about what they don't know. It's how they use their imagination and logic sense in relation to the subject. You're going to want to be somewhat accurate, such as that Mars is red or that Giraffes don't eat people.  Unless your story takes place in an alternate universe where you can bend the laws of reality, it's a very thin line when jumping into subjects you're unfamiliar with. But if you're providing scientific facts that simply aren't true, stating you're an expert in that field, don't be surprised to find people calling you out on that. Unless there's a logical explanation for why you wrote something, incomplete ideas about a subject you're not well familiar with will do more harm to your novel than good. So whatever you're attempting to write about, ensure that you do some sort of study about it. Don't simply go off of random facts that you may have heard on television or stereotypes that aren't true.  Explore the background of your story and imagine a separate reality there. If your novel takes place in Egypt, jump into a few studies regarding the land and its culture. If you're writing about space, look up a few books about stars and the universe. People do love imagination, but only to an extent. They also need realism so they could still relate to the story and feel connected with it.

Please, please, PLEASE write what you don't know. Write from your imagination and make a point of learning everything about whatever subject you imagine, but don't stick to what you know because the world is far too full of writers who don't know s**t but still try to write what they think they know. Become a student of the world and write what you learn and try to imagine things nobody  has imagined before. Every writing teacher I have ever had has said "write what you know."  It's bull.  Telling a class full of high school or college students to write what they know is to give credibility to the emptiness of their experience.  They should be encouraged to imagine and learn and be curious, and their writing should come from their questions, not from their answers, because in the end they don't know anything, and neither do you, and neither do I.  Do not write what you know because you are wise enough to know that you know nothing.  Write from a place of wonder.  Do not be so presumptuous as to think that what you know matters.

Yes, absolutely. I know people always say write what you know, but writing what you don’t know can be incredibly effective and powerful. Do your research on your topic and ask questions. As you learn about something you may explore new interests, and you see things from a unique point of view. If you’re writing about a place you’ve never been to, for example, you may include things that a person from there might take for granted. You may see things in a new light, and not be limited by the geography or the history of the place. I have one published novel and it’s about something I don’t know. In fact, it’s about multiple things I don’t know, but I wrote it from the pov of a character who is a bit of a fish out of water, which made it a little easier. I did a ton of research, however, so that my inexperience wouldn’t be as obvious.

This is sort of a trick question. Everything they write is an extension of something they know, so on a purely literal basis: no. But that doesn't mean that someone who writes a murder mystery has to go out and kill someone. Likewise for fantasy and science fiction authors who have never been to Middle Earth or Mars.  If a writer wants to write about something they don't know, they usually research it to whatever extent is necessary. People who aren't historians write historical fiction and authors who aren't aerospace engineers write about space battles. Google and Evernote make a lot of things possible! On the other hand, there are authors who write about topics they know nothing about and they don't do any research. They guess or fill in the blanks with made-up solutions. This doesn't always mean the work will be bad, but in genres like historical fiction or alternate history, it's likely to make a lot of readers unhappy. J. PaulThird Phase Publishing

You can write about anything; the question is, what will people think of it?  If you're writing "hard science fiction" or a novel set in the Northumbrian city of Leeds and make obvious technical errors, readers will not be kind. Do your research. If you're writing about an emotion you've never felt, I'm skeptical that it will move the reader. I suspect this is is also true if you're writing about sex you've never had, especially when it's sex your readers have had. Write about feelings you know.I agree with others that fiction is about things we don't know: things that didn't happen; people who don't exist; worlds that never formed. We don't know them. You make them real for the reader, by writing about them.

Yes, as long as they take some time to learn enough. You don't have to be an expert in everything you write about, but you should have some basic knowledge. That's why many writers contact experts in a field they're writing about -- those experts can answer the questions they have.  Writing a legal thriller? Talk to a lawyer or a cop. Writing a cozy mystery that takes place in a botanical garden? Talk to a horticulturalist.-------------------Edit:Look at JK Rowling. What did she write about? She wrote about a wizards' school, but it was modeled on typical British schools, so she knew something about it. She wrote about personality and ideological conflicts, which just about everyone knows about through experience with people. But mostly she wrote about an orphan, and his internal struggles -- and she did this because she felt like an orphan when her mother was dying of MS. She wrote what she knew, and any bits she didn't know, she could research.

Yes! The type of book, Novel, means "new." Novels are characterized as covering topics that are not often explored in other genres, such as mystery and romance, or by approaching the genre in a novel way. Given this nature, it is only to be expected that many novels concern things that no one has ever experienced or done, including the author.  However, to answer your exact question, things get more complicated. Many times, when the author doesn't know what they are writing about, such as some who has never taken a science course writing Science Fiction, the quality of the work suffers. That's not to say an ignorant author will always be bad; they just have to use their imagination and reasoning to compensate.

If people only wrote what they knew, nothing would ever be written. All learnings throughout time would have been passed down orally and never written down. Mundane facts would be written down like "There is a tree next to my cave." or "That bear ate my friend." or "When I stab myself, I bleed." We would never share what we learn, think, or imagine. Hence, we would never develop what we collectively learn, think, or imagine. Science, Art, Philosophy, and even Religion would remain in stagnant and infantile stages. So, yes, novelists should absolutely write about what they don't know. And so should everyone else sometimes. You can argue that I just did.

Do you think Queen Rowling is a witch??!! She came up with all those spells that no human ever knows, forget her. She invented new words even. She doesn't know magic, yet she created the most magical world and gave us the most magical childhood.Of course they can. It called imagination. Its what separates us from the machines!! Although a lot of novels require a lot of extensive research to lend artistic verisimilitude to an otherwise bald and uncongenial exposition, but at the end of the day, its fiction. They are usually banking on the fact that as much as they wished something existed, there are million others wishing the same too. That's what novelists know and that is all the fact he cares about. The rest is all made up my friend. Writers create, they don't catalog fact.

Yes, of course. Imagine, as best we can... From Zen and the Art of Writing:  "To gently lie and prove the lie true ... everything is finally a promise ... what seems a lie is a ramshackle need, wishing to be born." - Ray Bradbury  ... or from Illusions: The Adventures of a Reluctant Messiah:  "There was part of me listening that didn’t think what I said was fiction. I was making up a true story." - Richard Bach [Edited to add: The above is for writing what we don't consciously know. Still gotta learn... "feed the muse"!]

No. I don't think anyone can write about something they don't know.  Every author will know what he / she is writing about. She will know the universe she is creating, the characters and their motivations,  the plot and her conclusion of it.  It may not reflect reality but that's a completely different question isn't it? If everyone just wrote things that reflected facts of life then we will have nothing more than dry, anecdotal diaries of rich and famous or detailed academic text books.

You can but you should have at least basic knowledge of the topic. Stories aren't about setting, theyare about story. Setting is there just as mmeans of telling that story.  This is where the knowledge is important: You want the setting be immersive. You don't want the reader to be taken out of story by a glaring mistake in submarine design or space physics.  You need at least basic knowledge to avoid these mistakes, but there is no need to be expert in a field as average reader isn't too.

I think so, yes. The adage "Write What you Know" has truth to it, but if we took it literally then fiction would be a lot less exciting. I have always taken the adage to mean that in a general sense we all bring a piece of ourselves to our writing, but not necessarily that we can only write about experiences we've had personally. Please see my blog post "Write What you  . . . Know?" on @Anna Bradley - Historical Romance Writer

a novelist or anyone for that matter, according to me, can't write about something they haven't personally experienced or seen happen around them. if they have not had contact with something on any level, external or internal, their writing about it and sentiments about it would probably be insincere and transparent and unreliable for the people reading it.

Depends on your definition of "know."  I've never solved a murder, but I write mysteries.  I've never lived in a society where magic works, but I write fantasy.  I've never ventured off this planet, but I write sf.  And I've never travelled back in time to the trans-Mississippi in 1870, but I write Westerns.  All of which have met with reader approval. It's all in the research, I think.

Yes. This is the age of the information super highway. What authors don't know can be researched like never before in history. Google is one of the writers best and most used tools. The more accurate phrase might be: Novelists shouldn't write what they aren't passionate about.

By the very nature of the novel, the novelist obviously can write about things he/she doesn't know. Fiction writers write about things that they couldn't have experienced or known. Having said that, no writer worth his/her salt is going to write about something they don't know something about.

Sure. It's fiction. Do you think they research all those space travel, alien being stories?  It bothers me when someone corrects fictional stuff. I research mileage, terrain, weather, some anatomy necessities, even give sources sometimes, but when they say it couldn't happen, who knows for sure?   "I make stuff up."

If you're asking if they have to write from their life experience, then no.  A writer can do a lot of research and write a good novel. But they can't write when knowing nothing about a topic, situation or experience at all.
With enough research, a novelist can know things they didn't know before. I am not a math genius, but my protagonist is. I'm doing lots of research. :-)
Any novelist who writes about being anything other than a version of himself or herself is writing about things that he or she doesn't know from experience.

If you can imagine something, then you will know what is imagined. This may be far from a truth or the perception of others, but if it is a good story then go for it. The world would be an artistic wasteland if we only had representations of what was known.
I assume you are referring to the “rule” Write what you know. If you want to write about something, then you learn enough to write about it intelligently. Writers do it all the time.

Knowledge comes out of experience, experience through various sensory perceptions under various circumstances. Mind accumulated the knowledge of the humanity to visualize a situation. So there is no need to experience everything personally or knowledgeable in the area of writing where sometimes imagination and visualization takes the driving seat.
yes. It is possible.
its all imagination based on the fact.
